name: 1450 XLD
coprocessor: GTIA (video output, sprites), POKEY (sound, I/O), ANTIC (video, display lists), FREDDY (memory manager)
rom: 16 KB (the Basic is on a cardridge)
text: five text modes, max: 40 x 24, min: 20 x 12
ports: RGB, cartridge, Expansion port, Tape, RS232, Joystick
description:
The Atari 1450 XLD has the same characteristics as the Atari 1400 XL.

Like the 1400 XL, it has a built-in modem (Bell 103 compatible, 300 baud) and the speech synthesiser chip (SC-02). Contrary to the other Atari, it uses a parallel disk drive controller (a much faster arrangement) instead of the SIO interface.

Apparently The 1450 was not released because they were having problems getting the parallel disk drive controller to work properly.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LOGABAX STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>"What a quantum leap, Logabax!"<br> "I would say even more, what a quantum leap!"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://tintinomanie.chez.tiscali.fr/</b> © Moulinsart</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Stop everything !''<br> ''Atmos from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert price list:<br><br> 16K RAM: <b>$399</b> (kit)  <b>$459</b> (assembled)<br> Parity option: <b>$39</b> (kit)  <b>$59</b> (assembled)<br> Floating point board: <b>$259</b> (kit)  <b>$359</b> (assembled)<br> Z80 board: <b>$199</b> (kit)  <b>$259</b> (assembled)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-503 is a YIS-303 with more memory (32 kb) and a proper keyboard.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Imagine the new world that would unfold before you if you had a powerful , portable, completely integrated computer system at your personal disposal. And at an affordable price. That's exactly what Hewlett-Packard has just created.<br> At the lab, on your desk or in your study this 20-pound, self-contained  system provides professional computing power when and where you need it. That means no more waiting for data to be remotely processed and returned.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60, to show that the BIT-60 is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really  working ? ;-)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1982 HEATHKIT CENTERS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1946...</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an extract of the promotional guide. It says: <br><br> <font color="#666666">1946... Today the TO 7<br> 1946: 30 tons, 160 m²<br> Today: 3.5 Kg, 0.01 m²</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advertisement from a UK Sage dealer.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"access to the Forth power" <br><br> "with the Jupiter Ace, enjoy profesionnal experience of Forth"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the competition is dumb !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Before being told about it, come hear it yourself."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sharp 1211 advert from ILLEL, a french computer seller</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Karl-Heinz  -  www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Micro price, Mega features"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the previous advert showing the various cards of the Gemini 80-BUS system.</blockquote>

item.description: Indus GT|||5''/14 disk-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INDUS GT</strong></font><br><strong>> 5''/14 disk-drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Indus GT Double Density Drive is considered by many the best floppy drive available for the 8-bit Atari's with its digital readouts and smoke plexi cover.</blockquote>

Astra 2001 FD unit|||Dual 5.25|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ASTRA 2001 FD UNIT</strong></font><br><strong>> Dual 5.25</strong><br><blockquote>Dual 5.25" FDD unit using single side, single or double density floppy drives </blockquote>

Percom disc drive|||Advert|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PERCOM DISC DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> Advert</strong><br><blockquote>March 1983 Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The Percom Data AT-88 offers 88 Kbytes (formatted) in single-density, with plug-in ease of attachment to your Atari. The AT-88 has integral power supply, "no-patch" to Atari DOS and critical constant speed regulation.<br> Take advantage of this low introductory price of $488... </font> </blockquote>

Corvus Systems hard-drive|||10Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CORVUS SYSTEMS HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> 10Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a 10Mb hard-drive. With up to 8 multiplexers with 8 ports each it's possible to connect up to 64 Atari 800's up to a single 10 or even 20 megabyte Atari system. Still in use Today at the Fordham Prepatory School in the Bronx, NY is a 64 Atari 800 computer network hooked up to a single Corvus Hard drive system !  <br><br> The Corvus hard disk system also sported a unique and innovative back-up system called "The Corvus Mirror" which was a VCR interface system that allowed you to plug a standard Video Cassette Recorder (VCR) up to the Corvus Hard Drive System to save back-ups of the hard disk onto actual Video Tapes!!!</blockquote>

Touch Tablet||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOUCH TABLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>The touch tablet was the best tool for drawing and painting. It shipped with the AtariArtist cartridge.</blockquote>

emulator.name: The Atari 800 Emulator for the Mac
Atari++
emulator.description: Unix based emulator of the Atari eight bit computers, namely the Atari 400 and 800, the Atari 400XL, 800XL and 130XE, and the Atari 5200 game console

emulator.name: Atari800
emulator.description: Atari800 is an Atari 800, 800XL, 130XE and 5200 emulator for Unix, Amiga, MS-DOS, Atari TT/Falcon, SDL and WinCE
